empty_state.desc: Create a cost model to start calculating your hybrid cloud costs using custom price lists, markups, or both. Click on the "Create cost model" button below to begin the journey.
empty_state.title: What is your hybrid cloud costing you?

empty_state_rate.description: To add rates to the price list, click on the "Add" rate button above.

empty_state_source.description: Select the source(s) you want to apply this cost model to.

header.sub: A cost model allows you to associate a price to metrics provided by your sources to charge for utilization of resources.
header.title: Cost models

cost_models_details.sources_filter_results: cost model sources filter results toolbar

confirm.message: Are you sure you want to stop creating a cost model? All settings will be discarded.
confirm.title: Exit cost model creation

cost_models_wizard.description: A cost model allows you to associate a price to metrics provided by your sources to charge for utilization of resources.

empty_state.desc_create: To create a price list, begin by clicking the {{add_rate}} button.
empty_state.desc_other_time: You can create a price list or modify one at a later time.
empty_state.desc_skip: To skip this step, click the {{next}} button.
empty_state.title: A price list has not been created.

cost_models_wizard.inprogress_message: Please wait while processing the request

markup.invalid_markup_text: Markup must be a positive or negative number
markup.sub_title: To apply a markup to the base cost of your source(s), enter a positive percentage value. To apply a discount, enter a negative value (using -) to subtract from the base costs.
markup.title: Set a markup or discount (optional)

price_list.data_list_aria_label: Cost model price list data list
price_list.sub_title_add: Select the metric you want to assign a price to, and specify a measurement unit and rate. You can set one rate per metric in a price list.
price_list.sub_title_table: The following is a list of rates you have set so far for this price list.
price_list.title: Create a price list (optional)

review.sub_title_details: Review and confirm your cost model configuration and assignments. Click {{create}} to create the cost model, or {{back}} to revise.
review.sub_title_success: Costs for resources connected to the assigned sources will now be calculated using the newly created {{ cost_model }} cost model.

source.caption: Select from the following {{ type }} sources:
source.sub_title: Select the source(s) you want to assign the cost model to. Assigning a new cost model will overwrite any previous cost model assignments. You can also save your cost model and assign it to a source later.

source_table.table_aria_label: assign sources to cost model table

steps.sources: Assign a source to the cost model

cost_models_wizard.warning_override_sources: This selection will override the assignment of some cost models

dialog.delete_cost_model_body_green: This action will delete {{ cost_model }} cost model from the system. This action cannot be undone.
dialog.delete_cost_model_body_red: You must unassign any sources before you can delete this cost model.
dialog.delete_cost_model_body_red_costmodel_del: The following sources are assigned to my production cost model:
dialog.delete_source_from_cost_model_body: This will remove the assignment of {{ source }} from the {{ cost_model }} cost model. You can then assign the cost model to a new source.

markup.body: This action will delete the markup from the {{ cost_model }} cost model. Any calculations that can be made with this markup rate will no longer be available.
markup.title: Delete markup from {{ cost_model }} cost model?

aws_configure.cost_report: Create a cost and usage report using the following values:
aws_configure.enter_s3_bucket: Enter the name of the Amazon S3 bucket you just created in the S3 bucket field:
aws_configure.intro: To collect and store the information needed for cost management, you need to set up on Amazon S3 bucket for cost and  usage reports.
aws_configure.s3_bucket_account: Specify or create an Amazon S3 Bucket for your account.
aws_configure.s3_bucket_name_helper_text_invalid: S3 bucket name must start with alphanumeric character and can contain underscore and hyphen

configure.click_next: Click Next to finish adding the OpenShift cluster as a source.
configure.create_entry: Create a crontab entry to run the Usage Collector every 45 minutes:
configure.cron_user_more: To configure sudo access, add the following to the {{path}} file, substituting {{sub_text}} with the cron user:
configure.cron_user_req_1: Access to the file containing the {{metering_operator}} token
configure.cron_user_req_2: Sudo access to interact with the Red Hat Insights client
configure.edit_crontab: Open the crontab for the user that will execute this scheduled upload:
configure.entry_description: entry to run OCP Usage collector every 45 minutes
configure.explain_more_about_cron: more details about editing the crontab
configure.instructions_text: Create a cron job to regularly upload data collected by the Usage Collector to Cost Management.

notification.description: Additional recommendations based on this extra source will now appear in Insights.
notification.title: {{name}} was added successfully.

obtain_login.intro: To gather OpenShift Container Platform metering data, Cost Management requires the login token for the Reporting Operator service account.
obtain_login.obtain_token: Log in to the OpenShift Container Platform cluster with an account that has access to the Reporting Operator namespace.
obtain_login.popover_content: When you install Operator Metering for Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform, the {{metering_operator}} service account is created in the Reporting Operator namespace. {{learn_more}}
obtain_login.run_command: To obtain your login token, run:
obtain_login.run_command_aria_label: command line to obtain the token
obtain_login.security: To maintain security, store the token file on a file system with limited access.

source_kind.checkbox_1_aria_label: On your OpenShift cluster install: OpenShift Container Platform 3.11 or newer and Operator Metering.
source_kind.checkbox_2: On a system with network access to your OpenShift cluster, install:
source_kind.checkbox_2_aria_label: On your OpenShift cluster install: OpenShift Container Platform 3.11 or newer and Operator Metering.
source_kind.checklist_title: Before you begin, install the following prerequisites if not present:
source_kind.instructions_text: Enter a descriptive name to identify the source, and select a source type. All fields are required.

usage_collector.configuration_complete: When configuration is complete, you will receive a confirmation message that contains a cluster identifier. Enter that value in the cluster identifier field.
usage_collector.download_and_install: Download and install the {{usage_collector}} on the same system where the Red Hat Insights client is installed.
usage_collector.example_text: Use the following example, substituting values for your OpenShift API endpoint, Reporting Operator namespace, and {{reporting-operator}} token file path:
usage_collector.instructions_text: The Usage Collector connects to your cluster and collects the data required for cost management.
usage_collector.instructions_title: Download and configure the Usage Collector
usage_collector.navigate: Navigate to the {{korekuta_master}} directory to find the {{ocp_usage_sh}} script.
usage_collector.popover_clusterid_content: The cluster identifier value is stored in {{path}}
usage_collector.popover_cmd_content: If the oc command line is installed in a different location from /usr/bin/oc on your system, specify the path using -e OCP_CLI=</path/to/oc> when executing the ocp_usage.sh command.
usage_collector.run: Run the {{ocp_usage_sh}} script to configure the Usage Collector.
